Fig. 1 XRD patterns (A), nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms (B), and CO2 temperature programmed desorption curves (C) of FAU (1), Ru@FAU (2 and a), Na-Ru@FAU (3 and b), K-Ru@FAU (4 and c), Mg-Ru@FAU (5 and d), and Ca-Ru@FAU (6 and e) samples. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (A) HRTEM images of Ru@FAU and HADDF scanning transmission electron microscopy image and energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDX) mapping for Si, O, Al, Ru, Na elements, (B∼E) HRTEM images of Na-Ru@FAU, K-Ru@FAU, Mg-Ru@FAU, and Ca-Ru@FAU, respectively. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (A) High resolution XPS spectra of Ru 3p and (B) XPS spectra of O 1s for Ru@FAU (1), Na-Ru@FAU (2), K-Ru@FAU (3), Mg-Ru@FAU (4), Ca-Ru@FAU (5), (C) difference charge density of the RuO2-K (isosurface unit = 1 ×10–3 e/Bohr3, the blue area represents the loss of electrons, and the yellow area represents the gain of electrons), and (D) corresponding planar-average charge density curve along the Z axis. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (A) Proposed adsorption state of L-lysine on catalysts and ATR-IR spectra of the raw Ru@FAU (1), and samples after adsorption of 0.1 M L-lysine for 24 h and after heating at 80 ℃ overnight (Ru@FAU (2), Na-Ru@FAU (3), K-Ru@FAU (4), Mg-Ru@FAU (5), Ca-Ru@FAU (6)); (B) L-lysine adsorption capacity of different samples according to UV–Vis; (C) In situ ATR-IR spectra of L-lysine conversion over K-Ru@FAU at 200 °C and its alteration with reaction time in H2 atmosphere with a flow of 30 mL/min. The inserted image was the proposed surface intermediate. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (A) The ball and stick model of optimized structure and the adsorption energy (Ea) of L-lysine on RuO2, K/RuO2; (B) The three-dimensional spatial distribution map of the independent gradient model (IGM) (isosurface = 0.001 a.u.) for the Lys-K/RuO2 and corresponding scattered points plot. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Variation of conversion (A) and selectivity of cadaverine (B) with reaction time over different catalysts. Reaction conditions: 0.1 M Lysine, 0.101 g catalyst, H2 pressure of 2 MPa, 200 °C, pH = 2. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Conversion and selectivity of cadaverine at 10 min with different samples, the red star represents the absolute value of oxygen atoms with negative charges. Reaction conditions: 0.1 M Lysine, 0.101 g catalyst, H2 pressure of 2 MPa, 200 °C, pH = 2. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (A) Other by-products distribution at 10 min with different samples and their proposed conversion routes. (B) CH4 percentage in gaseous phase at 10 min, 20 min, 30 min, and 60 min over Ru@FAU, Na-Ru@FAU, K-Ru@FAU, Mg-Ru@FAU, and Ca-Ru@FAU catalysts during decarboxylation reaction. Reaction conditions: 0.1 M Lysine, 0.101 g catalyst, H2 pressure of 2 MPa, 200 °C, pH = 2. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Proposed mechanism of decarboxylation of L-lysine on K-Ru@FAU. Fig. 9 Scheme 1 Proposed reaction routes for L-lysine. The structure with red color was suggested to be active intermediate. Beijing Key Laboratory of Ionic Liquids Clean Process, CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Complex Systems, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. The synthesis of cadaverine from heterogeneous decarboxylation of L-lysine is of great significance for the industrial production of nylon 5X materials. However, it still remains as a great challenge with a low selectivity ∼50%. We herein report a strategy for selective decarboxylation of L-lysine via alkaline metal modification of heterogeneous catalysts, where the selectivity of cadaverine reaching 76% was obtained over K-Ru@FAU under optimized reaction conditions. K-Ru@FAU also exhibited high reactivity with a 100% conversion of L-lysine in one hour. Characterizations revealed that electrons transfer from alkaline metals to catalysts, leading to a greatly enhanced Lewis base properties of oxygen atoms with negative charges. It greatly facilitated chemical adsorption of L-lysine. Finally, reaction mechanism was proposed which contains chemical adsorption to carboxylate forms, activation to active surface carbonyl species, and decarbonylation to cadaverine. The alkaline metal modification provides a new route for directed decarboxylation of amino acids to primary amines. Graphical Abstract A strategy for selective decarboxylation of L-lysine to cadaverine was reported via alkaline metal modification of heterogeneous catalysts. A 76% selectivity of cadaverine was obtained over K-Ru@FAU under optimized reaction conditions. It provides a new route to designing efficient catalysts for directed decarboxylation of amino acids to primary amines. ga1 Keywords Decarboxylation L-lysine Cadaverine Ru clusters Nylon5X Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction Cadaverine has been widely accepted as an important monomer to produce petrochemical polymers, such as polyamides and polyurethanes [1]. Synthesis of cadaverine through decarboxylation of L-lysine has triggered great interests in both academics and industrial fields as the low cost of L-lysine and its large annual production of 1210 t/year. Presently, the biological decarboxylation of L-lysine is extensively studied with a high molar conversion yield and a high selectivity of cadaverine at moderate environment by fermentation [2] or whole cell bioconversion [3]. However, the toxicity of cadaverine for the cells and the expensive purification from dense broth with complex metabolites force us to pursue more economic, reusable and stable catalysts. Heterogeneous catalysts are attracting more and more interests in decarboxylation of amino acids as its easy separation from product and the reusing ability [4,5]. In 2017, commercial Ru/C catalyst was first reported to perform well in decarboxylation of L-lysine with a 32% yield of cadaverine [6], indicating that Ru-based heterogeneous catalyst is the key point for effective synthesis of cadaverine. Subsequently, Xie [7] reported that a more detail conditions optimum was carried out on Ru/C including reaction temperature, hydrogen pressure, and molar ratio of H3PO4 to L-lysine. Yield of cadaverine was improved to be 40% with a selectivity of 51%. Lv [8] prepared a series of supported Ru-based catalysts on silicon dioxide, alumina, zeolites and metal oxides via traditional wetness impregnation method. A serious agglomeration of ruthenium oxide nanoparticles was found in those catalysts, which might be blamed for the low yield of cadaverine. Ma [9] prepared a manganese (Mn) doped ruthenium oxide catalyst with Beta zeolite as support for decarboxylation of L-lysine. The Ru-Mn/Beta catalysts exhibited a high dispersion of ruthenium nanoparticles and performed well with a 54% selectivity of cadaverine. It shows that a high dispersion of ruthenium nanoparticles facilitates decarboxylation. To obtain ultrafine Ru nanoparticle we further prepared a zeolite-confined ruthenium catalysts by in situ hydrothermal method [10]. Ru nanoparticles was encapsulated in the supercage of FAU framework. An average size of nanoparticles was ∼1.5 nm, which maximized utilization of metal active sites. Ru@FAU exhibited an extraordinarily high cadaverine productivity of 480.3 g/L/h/mmol cat. It was 22.6 times of that with traditional supported catalyst (21.2 g/L/h/mmol cat). Although selectivity of cadaverine for Ru@FAU (39.7%) was not greatly enhanced it did bring new opportunities to effective decarboxylation of L-lysine. Tremendous efforts and works are still needed to realize directed synthesis of cadaverine. The low selectivity of cadaverine was due to the significantly high reactivity of L-lysine with two amine groups and one carboxyl group [7,11,12]. Either -NH2 groups or -COOH group in L-lysine molecule has an equal opportunity to participate catalytic reaction. Once -NH2 groups were adsorbed, L-lysine would be captured in a N-cycle catalytic process rather than a C-cycle, which was suggested to be mainly responsible for the low selectivity of cadaverine. Surface modification was widely utilized to realize the effective capture of targeted molecules or groups [13–19]. It clearly shows that the principle of acid-base reaction still works well in directed adsorption of molecules or groups. Considering the competition in adsorption of amine groups (base) and carboxyl group (acid) in L-lysine, it seems greatly meaningful to enhance the base strength of catalysts to realize directed adsorption of carboxyl group. It is generally accepted that the alkaline metal cations in zeolite structure play a role as Lewis acid sites and the adjacent oxygen atoms with negative charge (Oδ-) act as Lewis base sites [20]. Base properties of FAU zeolite can be greatly improved by modification with alkaline metal oxides (Na, K, Mg, Cs) which introduced strong or medium strong base sites [21]. Davis [22] prepared the modified FAU zeolite with cesium oxide and found a higher CO2 adsorption capacity than the raw zeolite. They further perceived that the adsorption heats was significantly lower than bulk cesium oxide, showing that the loaded cesium oxide in modified zeolite was not stoichiometric oxides with a more ionic Cs-O bond than its bulk phase compounds [23]. Hunger [24] confirmed that the base strength of Oδ- in host zeolite framework was greatly enhanced by the loaded cesium oxide by 13 C CP/MAS NMR. Li [25] systematically investigated a series of alkaline oxide modified FAU zeolites with a base properties gradient and revealed that the base strength of oxygen atoms with negative charge was greatly strengthened by electron donating derived from loaded alkaline oxides. It is clear that base properties of zeolite can be significantly promoted by further alkaline oxide modification. However, as we all know, no attentions have been given to promoting effect of introduced base sites from alkaline oxide on decarboxylation of L-lysine to cadaverine. Zeolite-confined Ru catalysts cannot realize the directed adsorption of carboxyl group in L-lysine as its weak base strength. The random adsorption of carboxyl group and amine group in L-lysine led to a low selectivity of cadaverine. In this work, a series of alkaline metal (Na, K, Mg, Cs) modified Ru@FAU catalysts were designed, providing oxygen atoms with negative charge (Oδ-) with a greatly strengthened Lewis base properties. The enhanced Lewis base properties are suggested to largely facilitate the selective adsorption of acidic carboxyl group rather than amine group in L-lysine and finally improve the selectivity of cadaverine. XPS and DFT calculation results showed that 0.3–0.9 eV was transferred to catalyst from alkaline metals. Those oxygen atoms with negative charge played an indispensable role in adsorption of L-lysine by directed capturing its carboxyl group. Adsorption capacity of L-lysine was exactly enhanced after modification. Different from our previous works, those modified catalysts exhibited an excellent performance in decarboxylation of L-lysine with a 76% selectivity of cadaverine. As far as we know, it is the highest selectivity of cadaverine at present in heterogeneous decarboxylation of L-lysine. Finally, a new mechanism for decarboxylation of L-lysine to cadaverine was proposed which contained three steps: chemical adsorption of L-lysine by H-bond, activation at Ru sites to form surface carbonyl intermediate, and finally decarbonylation to release cadaverine. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Materials All chemical reagents were used as accepted without further treatment. Ruthenium chloride hydrate (RuCl3·3 H2O), Sodium chloride (NaCl), Potassium chloride (KCl), Calcium chloride (CaCl2), magnesium sulfate (MgSO4), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), sodium aluminates (NaAlO2), silica solution (25–30 wt%), L-lysine monohydrochloride, and phosphoric acid (H3PO4) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Synthesis of Ru@FAU was shown as follows: 22.40 g NaOH was dissolved in 200 mL deionized water. 2.70 g NaAlO2 was added into the solution under continuously stirring. 101.44 g Silica solution was added drop by drop. Then 2.72 g RuCl3•3 H2O was added into the above mixture. After stirring 4 h, the mixture was transferred to a hydrothermal reaction vessel and crystallized at 100 ℃ for 12 h. The sample was obtained by centrifugation and washed by deionized water until pH of filtrate being neutral. Black powder was obtained after drying at 100 ℃ overnight. XRF results showed that the ruthenium amount in Ru@FAU sample was 4.646 wt%. Alkaline and alkaline-earth metal modified Ru@FAU samples (noted as M-Ru@FAU) were prepared by traditional wetness impregnation method and were noted as M-Ru@FAU, where M represents Na, K, Mg and Ca. For synthesis of Na-Ru@FAU, 0.07 g alkaline metal salt (NaCl) was dissolved in 1 mL deionized water. 0.70 g Ru@FAU was added into the solution and standing at room temperature for 12 h. The mixture was dried at 100 ℃ for 2 h and then calcinated at 400 ℃ with a rate of 5 ℃ /min in air for 3 h. For synthesis of K-Ru@FAU, Mg-Ru@FAU, and Ca-Ru@FAU, the alkaline metal salt was replaced by KCl, MgSO4, and CaCl2 respectively. 2.3 Characterizations The crystalline of samples were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Cu Kα radiation, 40 kV, 100 mA, λ = 1.5406 Å) with a speed of 5°/min from 10° to 80°. The morphology of samples were explored by Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM, FEI Quanta 200 SEM, FEI Company, Hillsboro, OR) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, Tecnai G2 F30/F20). The porous properties of samples including pore size and pore volume were tested by Micromeritics ASAP 2460 surface area and porosity analyzer. And the specific surface areas were calculated by Brunauer-Emmett−Teller (BET) method. The elemental compositions of samples were analyzed by XRF (APL Perform X4200). The base property of catalysts was determined by the temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 analyzer. The samples were loaded in a U-shaped micro-reactor and pretreated at 300 °C for 30 min under atmosphere of Ar. After cooling to 100 °C, the samples were saturated with CO2, followed by purging with Ar to remove physically adsorbed CO2. The desorption experiments were conducted under a stream of Ar (30 mL/min) by increasing temperature to 600 °C with a rate of 10 °C /min. The TPD signals were recorded simultaneously with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The acidity of catalysts was also conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 analyzer with NH3 as probe molecule following the same procedure as above. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer with an Al Kα = 1486.6 eV excitation source in ultrahigh vacuum (6.7 ×108 Pa), where binding energies (BE) were corrected by referencing the C1s peak (284.8 eV). FT-IR spectroscopy was recorded on BRUKER Tensor II analyzer in the range of 4000–400 cm-1 with an accessory of ATR. Sample was prepared as below: 0.1010 g catalyst was immersed in 10 mL 0.1 M L-lysine solution at room temperature for 24 h. After centrifugation, catalyst was washed with deionized water and then heated at 100 °C overnight. The obtained black powder was applied as test sample to give some information about adsorption of L-lysine on catalysts. In situ ATR-IR was also conducted on BRUKER Tensor II analyzer. The sample was pressed into a self-supporting disk and the put into a quartz cell sealed with CaF2 windows. The sealed cell was replaced first by N2 and subsequently by H2 for at least 1 h at room temperature. It was heated to 200 °C with a H2 flow of 30 mL/min to modulate the surface decarboxylation of L-lysine. The background of the unreacted precursors and raw catalyst at room temperature was subtracted. The adsorption capacity of samples was determined by measuring the change of L-lysine concentration before and after adsorption using UV–vis spectrophotometer at λmax of 210 nm. The used catalysts were studied by Thermal Gravimetric Analyzer (Melter TGA2, America) to give more information about deposits. The loss of Ru and alkaline metal ions in solution was analyzed by ICP-OES (Aglient 51110VDV). 2.4 Catalysts evaluation The mixture consisting of a solution of L-lysine hydrochloride (10 mL, 0.1 M) and a catalyst (0.101 g) was sealed in a high-pressure batch reactor (25 mL). The reactor was flushed with N2 for 8 times and then H2 for 8 times. Then the mixture was heated to the set temperature at 800 r/min with a pressure 2 MPa of H2. The reaction was stopped by quenching in ice water. The products were determined using HPLC-UV (Waters, C18 column, 100 Å, 5 µm, 4.6 mm × 250 mm) according to the method of our previous work. The detailed procedure has been reported elsewhere. To be brief, the solution was labeled by Dansyl Chloride and diluted 100 times with methanol. After filtration the product was analyzed by a liquid chromatograph equipped with a C18 column. The conversion of L-lysine was defined as (moles of consumed L-lysine)/(moles of initial L-lysine) and selectivity of cadaverine was calculated by (moles of cadaverine)/(moles of consumed L-lysine). Considering the fact that not all the N-containing products have a response, even after derivation, in the UV−vis characterization, we tried to detect other products by HPLC-Q-TOF-MS (AB Sciex X500R, UAS) with a C18 column (100 ×2.1 mm, Kinetex) and electrospray ionization (ESI). Methanol and water were applied as the mobile phase with a rate of 0.5 mL/min. The voltage of ESI was set 5.5 kV and − 4.5 kV to obtain the mass spectrometric measurements by scanning from 50 m/z to 1000 m/z. The byproducts, which contained piperidine, 2-hydroxymethylpiperidine, 2-methylpiperidine, lysinol, and 1,5-hexanediamine, were detected here. The gaseous product during decarboxylation of L-lysine was also detected by Agilent GC 8890B equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD, equipped with two HayesepQ columns and one Molecular sieve 5 A column) and a flame ionized detector (FID, equipped with a capillary column of HP-5). 2.5 Calculation method Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) based on density functional theory (DFT) was employed to explore the promoting effect of K on RuO2 [26,27]. Considering the practical environment of the catalytic reaction, the vacant coordination sites are saturated by hydroxyl groups or water. At the same time, the amino group of L-lysine was protonated (pH = 2). The structure of Ru11O44H28 was employed as the RuO2 cluster. The calculated lattice constants were a = b = 25.0 Å and c = 30.0 Å with α = β = γ = 90o. A vacuum layer was set to 20 Å for the RuO2 cluster to avoid the interaction of periodic structure. In structural relaxation, exchange and correlation effects were calculated via the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof functional (GGA-PBE). The self-consistency accuracy was set as 10-4 eV and the force convergence was set as 0.05 eV∙Å-1. And the plane wave energy cutoff was set as 400 eV. K-points were sampled in the Monkhorst-Pack grid for the first Brillouin zone integration [28,29]. Then, independent gradient model (IGM) based on promolecular density [30], which combined with the Multiwfn software [31], was employed to analyze interaction between L-lysine and the RuO2/K. The post-processing data of difference charge density was produced by the VASPKIT 1.3.3 software [32]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characterizations of modified catalysts As shown in Fig. 1A, the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Ru@FAU and M-Ru@FAU exhibited characteristic peaks of FAU framework. Ru@FAU showed a relatively high crystallinity of FAU, indicating that ruthenium addition had little effect on crystallization process of FAU zeolite. The absence of characteristic peaks corresponding to ruthenium metal or oxide crystal in Ru@FAU indicated no formation of large ruthenium particles. For M-Ru@FAU samples, characteristic peaks of FAU frame-structure exhibited an obvious shift, which suggested that modification of alkaline or alkaline-earth metal caused a distortion of crystal. Meanwhile, characteristic peaks of RuO2 for both amorphous and crystalline samples appeared after modification. It has been reported that FAU framework was inclined to suffer a relocation of metal elements after alkaline metal modifications [33], which should be mainly responsible for assembly of ruthenium particles. Crystal distortion and assembly of ruthenium particles clearly showed that an interaction existed between those alkaline or alkaline-earth metals and FAU frame-structure. As shown in Fig. 1B and Table 1, Ru@FAU suffered an obvious decrease of micropore volume from 0.217 to 0.177 cm3/g and surface area from 506 to 424 m2/g when compared to FAU, indicating that ruthenium nanoparticles were successfully encapsulated into FAU zeolite cavities or cages. The obvious increase of micropore porosity for those M-Ru@FAU (Table 1, entry 3–6) also proved a migration of encapsulated Ru clusters from internal micropore channels to external surface. On the other hand, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface of M-Ru@FAU retained well when compared to Ru@FAU indicating the accessibility of micropores in FAU zeolite. CO2-TPD profiles for all samples were given in Fig. 1. For the raw Ru@FAU sample, one main peak was found around 400 °C. The framework oxygen atoms with negative charge (Oδ-) of FAU zeolite was reported to exhibit Lewis base property with an CO2 desorption peak below 400 °C [25,34]. Therefore, the main peak found around 400 °C in Ru@FAU was attributed to Oδ- groups. Two broad shoulder peaks were observed which one was below 200 °C and the other was above 500 °C. The former shoulder peak below 200 °C was assigned to the adsorption of CO2 on weak base sites. As FAU zeolite was in its sodium ion type and calculated in air, the latter shoulder peak above 500 °C might be due to residual sodium oxide in Ru@FAU sample. For modified samples, the main desorption peak around 400 °C was largely broadened. The CO2 adsorption quantity was 0.388 mmol/g for Ru@FAU, which largely increased to 0.611 mmol/g for K-Ru@FAU. It indicated the promoted Lewis base strength of Oδ- in Na-Ru@FAU, K-Ru@FAU, Mg-Ru@FAU and Ca-Ru@FAU. High resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) and the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy were employed to further study dispersion of ruthenium nanoparticles in different samples ( Fig. 2). Ruthenium nanoparticles in Ru@FAU were found to disperse uniformly in FAU zeolite. They had an average particle size of 1.5 nm which was similar with that of α-cage (∼1.3 nm) in FAU framework, suggesting the successful encapsulation of ruthenium nanoparticles. EDX-mapping analysis exhibited a homogeneous distribution of ruthenium nanoparticles in Ru@FAU. After alkaline and alkaline-earth metal modification, ruthenium nanoparticles still remained a high distribution in M-Ru@FAU catalysts with an average particle size of 1.5–1.6 nm (Fig. 2B–E). Differently, M-Ru@FAU catalysts exhibited a rather rougher shape than Ru@FAU, which had some clustered particles on the edge of crystals. As shown by the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy in Figs. S1–S3, ruthenium element exhibited an obvious agglomeration on those clustered particles. Alkaline metal element (Na or K) or alkaline earth metal element (Mg or Ca) showed a uniform distribution in those agglomerated particles. Especially for Mg-Ru@FAU and Ca-Ru@FAU catalysts, no skeleton elements of Si and Al were founded in those particles. It seemed that those clustered particles were not the amorphous silicon aluminum oxides. Taking into account that diffraction peak of crystalline ruthenium oxide was observed at 28° and 35° in Fig. 1A, it suggested that those clustered particles with a particle size of 17–25 nm seemed to be clustered ruthenium oxide. Although parts of ruthenium nanoparticles were assembled on the external surface of crystals, the EDX mapping and high angle annular dark filed (HAADF) images of M-Ru@FAU showed that most of ruthenium nanoparticles were homogeneously located inside zeolite framework after modification. Therefore, modification did not significantly alter morphology and distribution of ruthenium nanoparticles in Ru@FAU. 3.2 Altered electronic properties of alkaline modified catalysts According to the principle of Sanderson electronegativity equalization below, different atoms will be adjusted to the same electronegativity to give a geometric mean value of electronegativity (Sint) of the compound when they are chemically combined [35]. Sint of catalyst reflects the acid-base properties of catalyst. It is widely accepted that the lower value of Sint, the stronger the base strength of catalyst [36]. Electronic information of different samples was listed in Table 2. Ru@FAU had a Sint value of 3.470. After alkaline or alkaline-earth metal modification, values of Sint in Na-Ru@FAU (Sint = 3.448), K-Ru@FAU (Sint = 3.409), Mg-Ru@FAU (Sint = 3.460), and Ca-Ru@FAU (Sint = 3.415) suffered a decrease. It suggested that base strength of zeolite framework was promoted by the loaded alkaline or alkaline-earth metal oxides. The oxygen atoms with negative charge (Oδ-) in framework act as Lewis base sites. Base strength of Oδ- was greatly enhanced after alkaline modification with a higher negative charge when compared with Ru@FAU. K-Ru@FAU showed the highest negative charge with a Oδ- value of 1.976. It clearly showed that the loaded alkaline metal chemically interacted with zeolite framework to alter its electronic properties [37], which is in consist with the distorted crystalline structure. High-resolution spectra of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) for Ru 3p with Ru@FAU and M-Ru@FAU were described in Fig. 3A. Due to the physics of the photoemission process and the resulting spin-orbit splitting of non s-levels or satellite structure from screened states, the Ru 3p binding energy peaks always exhibited a broad asymmetric peak as the natural asymmetric character of the 3p level. For Ru@FAU, a binding energy peak was observed at 462.8 eV which was assigned to Ru 3p3/2 for RuO2 [38]. After modification, the binding energy of Ru4+ shifted to a lower value in M-Ru@FAU. For example, the binding energy of Ru 3p3/2 decreased to 462.4 eV in Na-Ru@FAU, to 462.5 eV in K-Ru@FAU, to 462.1 eV in Mg-Ru@FAU, and to 462.1 eV in Ca-Ru@FAU. Considering the complexity of identification of Ru chemical state, XPS spectra of the Ru 3d core level was also conducted as shown in Fig S4. The binding energy peak at 280.7 eV in Ru@FAU was assigned to Ru 3d5/2 for Ru4+ [39,40]. After modification, the binding energy of Ru4+ also shifted to a lower value, which was in consistent with that of Ru 3p. The 0.3–0.7 eV shift of Ru 3p3/2 to a lower binding energy in those M-Ru@FAU catalysts confirmed the electron transfer between alkaline metals and Ru@FAU. XPS studies in Fig S5 showed that alkaline metal or alkaline-earth metal atoms existed in their ion forms which were bound to oxygen atoms [41]. Based on the principle of Sanderson electronegativity equalization, the electronegativity of metal oxides and zeolite will reach a new equilibrium value when alkaline or alkaline-earth metal oxides were inserted into Ru@FAU by chemical combination. As the Sint for Ru@FAU was higher than that of metal oxides, the negative charge will transfer from alkaline or alkaline-earth metal oxides to zeolite framework [42]. Additionally, we found an interesting phenomenon that more Ru atoms migrated to surface in those modified M-Ru@FAU samples (Table 2). Ruthenium atomic weight in surface was 1.89% with Ru@FAU, which grew up to 2.47–3.61% with M-Ru@FAU. It might be ascribed to the chemical interaction between alkaline metals and confined ruthenium atoms, leading to the obvious agglomeration of ruthenium oxide nanoparticles at crystal edge of those modified M-Ru@FAU compounds. The binding energy peaks of O 1 s with four pair peaks were given in Fig. 3B for different samples. For Ru@FAU sample, four fitting peaks were observed at 529.4, 530.8, 531.8, and 532.4 eV. O 1 s around 529 eV has been reported to be typical for metal-oxygen bonds [10,43]. So the fitting peak at 529.4 eV was assigned here to Ru-O lattice oxygen of RuO2 (noted as Oα1). O 1 s at 530.8 eV was attributed to surface oxygen O2 2-, O2- or O- of structural defect (Oα2). The fitting peaks at 531.8 eV (noted as Oβ) and ∼532.4 eV (noted as Oγ) were assigned to Si-O-Al and Si-O-Si linkages, respectively [44,45]. For Ru-O linkage of RuO2, the binding energy of Oα1 shifted obviously to a lower value with M-Ru@FAU samples after alkaline metal modification. It has been mentioned above that after alkaline metal modification electron was transferred from metal oxides to framework oxygen atoms (either zeolite or RuO2) according to the principle of Sanderson electronegativity equalization. The lower binding energy, the higher electron density. Therefore, the lower binding energy of Oα1 in M-Ru@FAU samples than that of Ru@FAU meant that lattice oxygen atoms of RuO2 obtained electrons from alkaline oxide after modification. It indicated that alteration of electronic properties caused by alkaline metal modification mainly focused on the active RuO2 sites. Contrarily, an obvious shift of Oα2 and Oβ to a higher binding energy was observed for M-Ru@FAU samples, especially for K-Ru@FAU. The binding energy of surface oxygen species caused by structural defects of zeolite in K-Ru@FAU was 531.2 eV, which was much higher than that of Ru@FAU (530.8 eV). The shift of Oα2 and Oβ to a higher binding energy in M-Ru@FAU samples indicated that alkaline metal also interacted with zeolite framework. To perceive the electron delivery between alkaline metal and Ru active sites, DFT method was applied (Fig. 3C, D). Difference charge density were employed to analyze the electron transfer between K and the RuO2 cluster. The charge distribution indicated that K would transfer electrons to the RuO2, which changed the electronic structure of the RuO2 and potentially facilitated L-lysine decarboxylation. Calculated by Bader charge [46], the K of a unit cell would donate 0.91 e- to the RuO2 in total. Meanwhile, planar-average charge density along the Z axis was shown in Fig. 4D. It was clear that electrons transfer mainly occurred at the interface of K and the RuO2. These results demonstrated that the K of a unit cell would donate 0.91 e- to the RuO2, which may promote the reaction kinetics. 3.3 Enhanced adsorption between L-lysine and catalysts ATR-IR spectra of different catalysts after adsorption of L-lysine were given in Fig. 4A. The peak assignments were summarized in Table S1 with some addition of our interpretation [47,48]. L-lysine was in its di-cationic form at pH = 2. For Ru@FAU catalyst, after immersion in a solution of 0.1 M L-lysine (pH 2.0), new adsorption peaks were seen in a range of 1800–1300 cm-1, indicating the successful adsorption of L-lysine. For more detail information, an extremely small peak for COOH was observed at 1735 cm-1. Meanwhile, two characteristic peaks at 1513 cm-1 for NH3 +sd (α-amino groups) and 1415 cm-1 for COO- ss were obtained. No peaks of side-chain amino groups (1526 cm-1) was seen after adsorption. The disappearance of COOH and side-chain amino groups indicated that L-lysine molecules might be laterally adsorbed on Ru@FAU catalysts. We have discussed above that oxygen atoms with negative charge in Ru@FAU can play a role as Lewis base. So, in the lateral adsorption, it seemed that both -COOH and side-chain NH3 + were captured through H-bonding interaction with those Lewis basic framework oxygen atoms. Different from side-chain amino group the characteristic peak of α-amino groups did not disappear after adsorption. It showed that α-amino group kept unaffected after adsorption, indicating that it had a higher stability than side-chain amino group. After alkaline metal modification, a small band for COO- as at 1559 cm-1 appeared in M-Ru@FAU catalysts. Close observation around 1513 cm-1 (NH3 +, α-amino group) revealed that a new shoulder peak emerged at 1508 cm-1 which was assigned to the adsorption of NH3 + side-chain amino group. The shift of NH3 + side-chain amino group from 1526 to 1508 cm-1 was ascribed to the strong interaction between L-lysine molecules and catalysts. It has been previously reported that the stronger interaction between L-lysine with supports, the lower wavenumber of NH3 + side-chain amino group [49]. New bands at 1474, 1456, 1448 cm-1 and 1386, 1375, 1339 cm-1 were assigned to CH2 scissoring and wagging vibration [50]. The emergence of COO- as at 1508 cm-1, as well as the shift of NH3 + side-chain amino group downward to 1508 cm-1, in M-Ru@FAU catalysts clearly showed that adsorption of L-lysine was greatly enhanced by alkaline metal modification. Especially, the appearance of COO- indicated that carboxyl group in L-lysine was chemically adsorbed on catalysts after modification as we have designed. As CO2-TPD results in Fig. 1 suggested, base property of framework oxygen atoms with negative charge (Oδ-) in zeolite was largely strengthened after alkaline metal modification. It was proposed that -COOH group was chemically adsorbed on basic Oδ- sites to release -COO-. Notably, adsorption peak at 1513 cm-1 (NH3 +, α-amino group) suffered no change in M-Ru@FAU. It suggested that α-amino group was stable which would not participate in further deamination to release N-containing by-products. Further, UV–Vis analysis was applied to verify the L-lysine adsorption [51]. The adsorption amount of L-lysine was determined here by measuring the variation of L-lysine concentration before and after adsorption using UV–Vis analysis at λmax of L-lysine at 210 nm (Figs. 4B, S6). It showed that Ru@FAU had an adsorption capacity of 4.6 mmol/g for L-lysine, which decreased seriously to 3.4 mmol/g for Mg-Ru@FAU and even to 2.8 mmol/g for Ca-Ru@FAU. L-lysine has different dissociation states (di-cationic, cationic, zwitterionic, and anionic) in solution which strongly depends on pH values and exists in its di-cationic form at pH = 2 [52]. Although base strength of oxygen atoms with negative charge was promoted after alkaline metal, it seemed that the repulsive force might existed between Mg2+ or Ca2+ with di-cationic L-lysine molecules. The repulsive force trumped the attractive electrostatic interaction, leading to a decreased adsorbed capacity for L-lysine in Mg-Ru@FAU and Ca-Ru@FAU. On the other hand, the extra-introduced Na+ in Na-Ru@FAU and K+ in K-Ru@FAU did not result in a decrease of adsorbed capacity of L-lysine when compared with parent Ru@FAU. It indicated that oxygen atoms with negative charges played a constructive role in adsorption of L-lysine, which was able to counteract with the electrostatic repulsion between Na+ or K+ with di-cationic L-lysine. The adsorption behavior of L-lysine on solid materials has been widely studied. The driven force for adsorption of L-lysine was supposed to be electrostatic interaction or H-bonding or both of them which largely depends on the given system [47,49,53,54]. Fig. 4C showed the in situ differential ATR-IR spectra of L-lysine conversion on K-Ru@FAU at 200 °C. The background of the unreacted precursors and raw K-Ru@FAU at room temperature was subtracted. The negative peaks in the range of 1800–1300 cm-1 suggested the desorption or conversion of L-lysine during heating process. A new peak at 1684 cm-1 appeared immediately in the range of CO (1800–1600 cm-1) once temperature up to 200 °C. This band is likely attributed to surface-adsorbed carbonyl species (R-C*=O) [55]. Extending the reaction time the intensity of R-C* =O group at 1684 cm-1 became higher. It suggested that the adsorbed L-lysine with its initial carboxylate forms (-COO-) was activated to be highly active surface intermediates (R-C*=O) in atmosphere of hydrogen. On the other hand, this peak did not appear at temperature lower than 200 °C, indicating that hydrogenation of L-lysine to 2,6-diamino-1-hexanal was a slow step with a high activation energy barrier. Also, a broad peak at 1218 cm-1 appeared with accumulation of the surface carbonyl species, which is the characteristic peak of ω(CH2) in aldehyde molecules [55]. As we all know, H2 could occur dissociation adsorption on Ru clusters to give active H·species. If H·attacked the surface carbonyl species through the C-Z bond (Z represented the zeolite), 2,6-diamino-1-hexanal would be obtained. The assumption has been widely reported that L-lysine was first hydrogenated to 2,6-diamino-1-hexanal and then 2,6-diamino-1-hexanal occurred decarbonylation to release cadaverine [4–10]. The appearance of R-C* =O group at 1684 cm-1 and that of ω(CH2) in aldehyde molecules at 1218 cm-1 proved the partial hydrogenation of L-lysine. To clarify interaction between L-lysine and catalysts, a simplified calculation model was given in Fig. 5. It should be noted that in this work RuO2 was regarded as the main active sites for decarboxylation of L-lysine to give cadaverine. We also got a good performance when applying pure RuO2 standard as the catalyst of decarboxylation. To simplify the calculation we chose RuO2 as the prototype of catalyst. The effect of K introduction on the catalytic effect was further investigated by calculating the adsorption energy of L-lysine. In simulation, the amino group of L-lysine was protonated due to actual reaction conditions of pH = 2. Before structural optimization, H1 belonged to an amino group and H2 belonged to a carboxyl group. However, after structural relaxation as shown in Fig. 5A, H1 transferred to the carboxyl group, while H2 transferred to the surface hydroxyl group of the RuO2 or RuO2/K to form surface water adsorbing species. Moreover, the adsorption energy (Ea) of L-lysine was − 5.38 eV for the RuO2/K, which was much lower than that of pristine RuO2 cluster (−4.57 eV). It should be noted that this simulation was conducted on a simplified model without considering effect of FAU zeolite, which was supposed to be further done in our future work. But the change of adsorption energy on the simplified model suggested that L-lysine was more favorable to be adsorbed after the introduction of K, which would facilitate the reaction kinetics of L-lysine decarboxylation. Although the enhanced adsorption of L-lysine after alkaline metal modification by macroscopic characterizations such as UV–Vis in Fig. 4B, the lower adsorption energy of L-lysine in RuO2/K showed that alkaline metal modification did do a favor for effective adsorption of L-lysine in a microscopic level. To further explore adsorption interaction for L-lysine, IGM analysis was performed via the Multiwfn software [56]. As depicted in Fig. 5B, IGM three-dimensional spatial distribution map revealed that strong interaction (blue and green ball area) existed between L-lysine and the RuO2/K [57]. Furthermore, the value of δg can measure the interaction between fragments following the larger the value, the stronger the interaction principles. There were two peaks around the position of sign(λ2)ρ = −0.05 and − 0.08. These results indicated that strong interaction between L-lysine and the RuO2/K mainly formed through -O-H…O hydrogen bonds, which could be contributed to the adsorption of L-lysine. 3.4 Directive decarboxylation of L-lysine to cadaverine Time profiles of conversion of L-lysine and selectivity of cadaverine with different catalysts were given in Fig. 6. For all the samples, conversion of L-lysine increased with reaction time and reached 100% at 60 min, indicating those catalysts exhibited a high reaction activity during the whole catalytic process. But an obvious decrease of L-lysine conversion was observed for those modified M-Ru@FAU samples at the initial period, indicating a significant loss of the initial activity of Ru@FAU after modification. For example, conversion of L-lysine was 65% with Ru@FAU in 10 min, but it dropped largely to 20% with Na-Ru@FAU and 25% with K-Ru@FAU. The conversion of L-lysine with Mg-Ru@FAU and Ca-Ru@FAU was little better than the former two catalysts, but also lower than 33%. Obviously, alkaline metal modification caused a damage of the initial activity of Ru@FAU. As shown in Fig. 6B, selectivity of cadaverine with Ru@FAU in 10 min was 40%. It increased to 50% for Na-Ru@FAU and even significantly rose up to 76% for K-Ru@FAU. It indicated that selectivity of cadaverine was largely enhanced after alkaline metal modification. On the other hand, stability of catalyst is an essential factor for assessment of feasibility of its industrial application. Stability tests of K-Ru@FAU catalyst were conducted under the optimized conditions. As described in Fig S7, conversion of L-lysine and selectivity of cadaverine did not decrease after 5 cycles, indicating that K-Ru@FAU bear a superior regeneration ability. A linear relationship was clearly obtained between selectivity of cadaverine and the negative charge of framework oxygen atoms (Oδ-) as described in Fig. 7. The higher negative charge of Oδ-, the higher electron density of oxygen atoms. Catalysts with a higher Oδ- greatly facilitated the desorption of N-containing chemicals, subsequently avoiding further side-reaction to obtain a high selectivity of cadaverine [58]. As shown. in Table 1, K-Ru@FAU showed a greatly enhanced Lewis base property with a highest negative charge of Oδ- (−1.976), which explained well the highest cadaverine selectivity with K-Ru@FAU sample. A different variation in cadaverine selectivity was observed for Mg-Ru@FAU. The oxygen atoms with negative charges in Mg-Ru@FAU sample showed a higher electron density (Oδ- = −1.920) than that of Ru@FAU (Oδ- = −1.909). It was probably concluded that Mg-Ru@FAU had a higher selectivity of cadaverine than Ru@FAU. But it slightly decreased from 40% with Ru@FAU to 37% for Mg-Ru@FAU. It should be noted that the electrostatic repulsion between Mg2+ with the bicationic L-lysine played a negative role in adsorption of L-lysine with a low adsorption capacity as given in Fig. 4B. Though Mg-Ru@FAU had a more negative oxygen atoms, the electrostatic repulsion triumphed over attraction leading to a decreased selectivity of cadaverine in the initial reaction stage. Selectivity of cadaverine was found to decrease with reaction time after reaching a peak value for all the catalysts, which was due to its further side reaction to generate piperidine, followed by an increase of peak intensity of piperidine. The initial byproduct distribution in 10 min was given in Fig. 8 according to LC-MS analysis data. The proposed three main reaction routes for L-lysine containing C-cycle and N-cycle were also given in Scheme 1. It was obvious that the intensity of piperidine suffered a loss after alkaline metal modification. It has been reported previously that cadaverine is not stable in the Ru-catalytic system which could further occur deamination to release piperidine. The lower intensity of piperidine in those modified M-Ru@FAU catalysts indicated a greatly enhanced desorption of cadaverine avoiding its subsequent side reactions. It has been discussed above that the negative framework oxygen atoms (Oδ-) in M-Ru@FAU samples have a higher electron density when compared with Ru@FAU, leading to an easy desorption of cadaverine. Intensity of 2-methylpiperidine was also observed to decrease in M-Ru@FAU samples. 2-methylpiperidine was supposed to be generated through the route 3 which contained the deamination of L-lysine to 2-piperidinecarboxylic acid, hydrogenation of 2-piperidinecarboxylic acid to 2-hydromethylpiperidine, and further deep hydrodeoxygenation to 2-methylpiperidine. The intensity of two intermediate compounds, 2-piperidinecarboxylic acid and 2-hydroxymethylpiperidine, did not decrease as that of 2-methylpiperidine in M-Ru@FAU samples. It seemed that alkaline modification inhibited the deep hydrodeoxygenation side reaction. For decarboxylation of L-lysine to cadaverine, it was widely accepted that L-lysine was first hydrogenated to 2,6-diamino-1-hexanal and then 2,6-diamino-1-hexanal occurred decarbonylation to give cadaverine with releasing one molecule of carbon monoxide [6]. As 2,6-diamino-1-hexanal performed a relatively high reactivity it had not been reported to be visually observed. The increased intensity of lysinol as well as that of cadaverine in M-Ru@FAU samples indicated that alkaline metal modification did do a favor for transfer of L-lysine to 2,6-diamino-1-hexanal. For gaseous phase product analysis, no CO was detected by GC-TCD for all the samples. Instead, methane was the main gaseous product with little amount of C2∼C4 olefins (Fig. 8B). It has been reported that CO derived from decarbonylation of 2,6-diamino-1-hexanal could undergo methanation at high reaction temperatures. Obviously, those modified M-Ru@FAU samples showed a higher amount of methane than Ru@FAU. The higher amount of methane, the higher amount of CO originated from decarbonylation of 2,6-diamino-1-hexanal. It again showed that alkaline metal modification was helpful for synthesis of cadaverine. Thermogravimetry analysis of those used samples are given in Fig S8. It was obvious that two clear weight loss peaks are found for all those samples. The first weight loss peak begins at 100 °C, which is ascribed to the physically adsorbed species or residual water. The second weight loss peak for those used catalysts is around 300 °C. Thomas et al. [59] reported the detail study of deactivation of Pt catalysts in decarboxylation of butyric acid within a fixed bed reactor. They observed the coke deposited on Pt catalysts were small molecules with the appearance of unsaturated C-C bonds stretches at 1530 cm-1 and 1440 cm-1, and the activity with similar efficiency could be restored after treatment at 350 °C. It indicates that in our experiments no large and condensed aromatic structures adhered strongly to the surface. The N, O, C organic elements analysis in Fig S9 shows that the deposit compounds might be most possible to be N-containing chemicals, such as the piperidine, aliphatic amines, or caprolactam. 3.5 Proposed mechanism Based on the above, we propose a mechanism for decarboxylation of L-lysine to cadaverine as Fig. 9. Step 1) Chemical Adsorption. The oxygen atoms with negative charges (Oδ-) in FAU framework played a role of Lewis base. After alkali metal (such as K) modification, electron transferred to Ru@FAU catalysts, leading to a greatly enhanced electron density of Oδ-. DFT calculation results in Fig. 5C, D and ATR-IR in Fig. 5A indicated that L-lysine was first laterally adsorbed through H bond interaction. Oδ- was supposed to captured the proton of carboxyl group rather than that of -NH3 + groups in di-cationic L-lysine to trigger the chemical adsorption of L-lysine. L-lysine was then chemically adsorbed on catalyst surface with its carboxylate forms. The peak of carboxylate was observed at 1414 and 1559 cm-1 in Fig. 5A. Step 2) Activation. H2 occurred dissociated adsorption on Ru clusters to release two active H·species. At high reaction temperature of 200 °C, active H·species attacked carboxylate group. After releasing one molecule of water, the active surface carbonyl intermediate was obtained with a characteristic peak at 1684 cm-1. Step 3) Decarbonylation. The surface carbonyl intermediate was very active. With the help of active H·species, it occurred decarbonylation to give cadaverine. And at the same time, one molecule of CO was released. CO can be further adsorbed by Ru clusters to undergo methanation to produce methane. Moreover, the active carbonyl intermediate can also occur hydrogenation to give lysinol, deamination to 2-hydroxymethylpiperidine. 4 Conclusions In summary, a novel strategy capable of highly selective decarboxylation of L-lysine was proposed on heterogeneous zeolite-confined Ru catalysts. We demonstrated that alkaline metal modification greatly enhanced Lewis base strength of catalysts via electron transfer, which significantly facilitated adsorption of L-lysine and desorption of cadaverine. In particular, the high selectivity of cadaverine reaching 76% was obtained with K-Ru@FAU under the optimized conditions. K-Ru@FAU also exhibited high reactivity with a 100% conversion of L-lysine in one hour. Oxygen atoms with negative atoms in FAU framework played a vital role in chemical adsorption of L-lysine. Moreover, the mechanism for decarboxylation of L-lysine was proposed which contained three steps: chemical adsorption to carboxylate forms, activation to surface carbonyl intermediate, and finally decarbonylation to cadaverine with releasing methane byproduct. Those findings would present enormous potential and advantages in the industrial production of cadaverine in the future. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of cadaverine from heterogeneous decarboxylation of L-lysine is of great significance for the industrial production of nylon 5X materials. However, it still remains as a great challenge with a low selectivity ∼50%. We herein report a strategy for selective decarboxylation of L-lysine via alkaline metal modification of heterogeneous catalysts, where the selectivity of cadaverine reaching 76% was obtained over K-Ru@FAU under optimized reaction conditions. K-Ru@FAU also exhibited high reactivity with a 100% conversion of L-lysine in one hour. Characterizations revealed that electrons transfer from alkaline metals to catalysts, leading to a greatly enhanced Lewis base properties of oxygen atoms with negative charges. It greatly facilitated chemical adsorption of L-lysine. Finally, reaction mechanism was proposed which contains chemical adsorption to carboxylate forms, activation to active surface carbonyl species, and decarbonylation to cadaverine. The alkaline metal modification provides a new route for directed decarboxylation of amino acids to primary amines.
coredata.dc:title: Directed synthesis of nylon 5X key monomer cadaverine with alkaline metal modified Ru@FAU catalysts
